title: Linguistics
description: A progressive exploration of the core concepts, subfields, and methodologies used in the scientific study of human language.

paragraphs.summary: An introduction to Linguistics as the scientific study of language, encompassing its structure, history, acquisition, use, and cognitive underpinnings.
Exploring key characteristics of human language, such as arbitrariness, duality of patterning, productivity (creativity), displacement, and cultural transmission.
Distinguishing prescriptive grammar (how language 'should' be used) from descriptive grammar (how language is actually used by speakers).
The study of how speech sounds are produced by the human vocal apparatus (lips, tongue, vocal cords, etc.).
The study of the physical properties of speech sounds as they travel through the air (e.g., frequency, amplitude, duration).
The study of how speech sounds are perceived by the listener's auditory system and processed by the brain.
An alphabetic system of phonetic notation based primarily on the Latin script, used to represent all known speech sounds.
The study of the sound systems of languages and the abstract patterns of sounds and their permissible combinations.
The smallest units of sound in a language that can distinguish one word from another (e.g., /p/ and /b/ in 'pat' vs. 'bat').
Variations in the pronunciation of a phoneme that do not change meaning and occur in predictable phonetic environments.
Pairs of words that differ by only one phoneme in the same position, used to identify the phonemes of a language.
Rules that describe how phonemes are realized as allophones in different phonetic contexts or how sounds change when morphemes combine.
The organization of sounds within a syllable, typically consisting of an onset (initial consonant(s)), nucleus (vowel), and coda (final consonant(s)).
Features of speech that go beyond individual phonemes, such as stress, pitch (intonation), rhythm, and tempo, conveying meaning and emotion.
The study of the internal structure of words and the rules by which words are formed from smaller meaningful units.
The smallest grammatical units in a language that carry meaning (e.g., 'un-', 'kind', '-ness' in 'unkindness').
Free morphemes can stand alone as words (e.g., 'cat'), while bound morphemes must be attached to other morphemes (e.g., prefixes like 'un-', suffixes like '-ed').
The modification of a word's form to express grammatical functions or attributes such as tense, mood, person, number, gender, and case.
The process of forming new words from existing words, often by adding affixes, which may change the word's meaning or part of speech.
Various ways new words are created in a language, including affixation (prefixes, suffixes), compounding, conversion, clipping, and blending.
The study of the rules and principles that govern how words are combined to form phrases and sentences in a language.
The concept that sentences are not just strings of words but are organized into hierarchical grammatical units called constituents (phrases).
Formal rules that describe how phrases can be constructed from smaller phrases or words, often represented as tree diagrams.
The functional relationships between constituents in a sentence, such as subject, direct object, indirect object, and predicate.
A theory of grammar (notably by Noam Chomsky) that posits underlying 'deep structures' which are converted into 'surface structures' (actual sentences) by transformational rules.
A linguistic theory proposing that humans are born with an innate set of grammatical principles common to all languages.
The branch of linguistics concerned with the meaning of words, phrases, and sentences, and how meaning is constructed and interpreted.
The study of word meanings and the relationships between them (e.g., synonymy, antonymy, hyponymy).
The study of how the meanings of individual words combine to form the meanings of phrases and sentences, based on syntactic structure (Principle of Compositionality).
The study of how context contributes to meaning; how language is used in social situations and how speakers convey more than what is literally said.
The theory that uttering a sentence is not just saying something but also performing an action (e.g., requesting, promising, warning).
Information that is conveyed by an utterance beyond its literal meaning, inferred by the listener based on context and conversational principles (Gricean maxims).
The study of how languages change over time, including sound changes, grammatical changes, and the reconstruction of proto-languages.
Groups of languages that are related through descent from a common ancestral language or proto-language (e.g., Indo-European, Sino-Tibetan).
The process by which humans acquire the capacity to perceive and comprehend language, as well as to produce and use words and sentences to communicate.
The study of how individuals learn languages other than their native tongue, including factors affecting the process and theories of learning.
The study of the relationship between language and society, including language variation, dialects, language attitudes, and language policy.
The study of linguistic dialects, regional or social varieties of a language distinguished by pronunciation, grammar, or vocabulary.
The study of the psychological and neurobiological factors that enable humans to acquire, use, comprehend, and produce language.
The study of the neural mechanisms in the human brain that control the comprehension, production, and acquisition of language.

An interdisciplinary field concerned with the statistical or rule-based modeling of natural language from a computational perspective, as well as the study of computational approaches to linguistic questions.
The study of language as expressed in samples (corpora) of 'real world' text, using computational methods to analyze patterns of language use.
The study of language in use beyond the sentence level, examining how larger linguistic units like conversations, texts, or narratives are structured and understood.
The study and interpretation of texts from a linguistic perspective, focusing on the style of language used and its effects.
The classification of languages according to their structural features (e.g., word order, morphological type) to identify patterns and universals.
The study of languages that are at risk of falling out of use as their speakers die out or shift to speaking another language.
Attempts by linguists and community members to halt or reverse the decline of an endangered language or to revive an extinct one.
The application of linguistic knowledge, methods, and insights to the forensic context of law, including authorship attribution and language analysis in legal cases.
Languages that use manual communication and body language to convey meaning, as opposed to acoustically conveyed sound patterns; fully formed natural languages with their own grammar and lexicon.
Methods of visually representing verbal communication, based on a script and a set of rules regulating its use (e.g., alphabetic, syllabic, logographic).
Exploring the relationship between the language one speaks and the way one perceives and conceptualizes the world (linguistic relativity/determinism).
The study of the intricate connections between language and cultural practices, beliefs, values, and social structures.
An interdisciplinary field that identifies, investigates, and offers solutions to language-related real-life problems, such as language education, translation, and policy.
